section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This hands-on programming section explores the essentials of variables and data types in Python, providing interactive exercises to reinforce concepts through practical coding. Learners will write code to manipulate variables, understand type distinctions, and apply data types in simple programs, building confidence in Python fundamentals.
learning_objectives: Declare and assign variables using appropriate syntax in Python scripts
Identify and utilize primitive data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans
Perform basic type conversions to handle data interchangeably
Apply variables and data types in expressions and simple computations

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create and modify variables using Python's assignment operator in code snippets
key_topics: Using the equals sign for variable assignment
Scope of variables in simple scripts

exercises.exercise_title: Create a Personal Info Variable Set
exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a Python script that declares variables for your name (string), age (integer), and height (float), then reassign the age to age plus one and print all values
Declare two integer variables a and b with values 5 and 10, then swap their values using a temporary variable and print the results before and after swapping

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Integer and Float Data Types
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform arithmetic operations on integers and floats while recognizing type behaviors in Python
key_topics: Integer literals and operations like addition and division
Mixed-type arithmetic resulting in float outcomes
Using type() function to inspect data types

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for two integers and one float, compute their sum, difference, product, and division, then use type() to verify the result types and print them
Declare a float variable for Celsius temperature (e.g., 25.5), convert it to Fahrenheit using the formula (c * 9/5) + 32, store in a new variable, and print both values with their types

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to concatenate strings and evaluate boolean expressions using variables in Python code
key_topics: String literals with single or double quotes
String concatenation with the plus operator
Boolean values True and False in comparisons

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare string variables for first_name and last_name, concatenate them with a space and 'hello' prefix, assign to a greeting variable, and print it along with its type
Create an integer age variable, use comparison operators to create a boolean is_adult variable (age >= 18), then print the boolean value and use type() to confirm its data type

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert variables from one data type to another using built-in functions in practical scenarios
key_topics: str() and float() for type casting in operations
Implicit vs explicit type conversion examples

exercises.exercise_instructions: Declare a string variable with numeric content like '42', convert it to an integer using int(), add 8 to it, convert the result back to string, and print the final string value

Create an integer variable and a string variable with a number, convert the string to float, add them together, then convert the sum to string for concatenation with another string and print the result
